audio_caption: The clip begins with dramatic, suspenseful music with a serious and urgent mood, featuring orchestral instruments. This quickly transitions to a male speaker, who introduces himself as "Professor Jim Kathy" and announces he will be discussing chapter 18 on stars, a celestial census, continuing their "examination of stars".

The clip features one male speaker describing the variety of stars in space, noting their differences in color, size, temperature, and mass. He speaks in a neutral, informative tone, cataloging the various attributes.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing stars, stating that the closest stars are "about four and a quarter light-years away" and that when we see them, we are "back in time." The speaker is calm and measured.

A male speaker begins by stating that they are the closest, then notes that the sun is "eight light minutes away." Continuing, he clarifies that when you see the sun, you're seeing how it looked eight minutes ago, "not now."

The clip begins with one male speaker, who describes himself as an "expert" in "binary stars." He mentions a "visual binary," specifying it as a "cool L-dwarf binary," and notes that it rotates in space over time. The speaker indicates the process is lengthy, then his speech concludes.

A man is speaking in a conversational tone about binary star systems, explaining that you can have stars of "really any mass" and that high mass stars "kill off the low mass stars" by absorbing them. He then mentions observing the motions of stars in a binary system by looking at the spectrum.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing a "spectrum" where "dark absorption lines" shift, particularly noticeable in certain pictures. He explains that this motion indicates movement towards or away, referencing red shifts and blue shifts. He then mentions that "tangential motion" cannot be detected if objects move sideways. Next, the speaker introduces these measurements as "radial velocities." Finally, a sound of speaking or speech occurs.

The clip features one male speaker discussing the study of eclipsing binary systems, explaining how images and light brightness measurements are taken and combined with radial velocities to get a full picture. His tone is informative and enthusiastic. The background is quiet.

A man speaks with an excited tone, noting he likes a certain feature that lets him zoom in to talk, making him feel like he's in a classroom. He transitions to talking about failed stars, specifically brown dwarfs, explaining their properties and comparing them to yellow dwarf stars. He mentions the mass luminosity relationship with some stars, and the clip ends with silence.

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker talking about "yellow big stars" and "white dwarf stars." He then states what he did for 20 years in his research with NASA at Missouri State University. The speaker has a conversational and informative tone.

The audio begins with a speaker mentioning taking an image of two stars and collecting all the light, explaining that they can obtain a light curve to measure changes in brightness over time in an eclipsing binary system, noting its use in other areas of astronomy. The speaker explains that you can't see the two stars separately through a telescope, so they use this method to get spectra and photometry. The speaker's tone is explanatory and slightly academic.

The clip features one male speaker expressing regret, mentioning his telescope at the university lacked a spectrograph and how that prevented him from getting "radio velocity measurements" and "a full picture" of what he desired. The speaker uses a relatively serious and slightly frustrated tone.

The clip begins with a male speaker describing an eclipse within a binary system, explaining the behavior of stars during the eclipse. He mentions a "total eclipse" followed by the "coming out of eclipse." The tone of speech is informative and explanatory. Then, he states that two men were giants in astronomy.

The audio begins with a single speaker, seemingly male, discussing the discovery of a relationship between luminosity and surface temperature of stars, culminating in the mention of the "HR, Henry Norris Russell Hertzsprung-Russell diagram" spoken with an informative tone. This transitions to a musical segment featuring a spacey, ambient sound, enhancing a sense of depth and vastness.

The audio features one male speaker, discussing "F-stars," explaining that they're normal stars that burn hydrogen and fall on a "main sequence." He describes these stars as being in their "adult lives," mentioning protostars as "babies." He mentions how long the sun will burn.

The audio features a single male speaker giving a lecture about stars and their characteristics. He discusses main sequences, charts, temperature and brightness measurements, spectral classes, surface temperature, and different types of stars such as super giants, red giants, red dwarf stars, binary stars, and dead stars like white dwarfs. He uses an enthusiastic tone while explaining the topic. Then, he emphasizes the relative sizes of stars using the example of the sun and VY Canis Majoris, describing the latter as "obnoxious." The speaker introduces a visual comparison where the sun appears as a tiny dot compared to VY Canis Majoris, emphasizing the size difference.

A male speaker with a neutral tone announces "we have seen a dwarf companion star, a white dwarf around a very famous bright star called Sirius, the dog star." He then concludes with "that's going to complete the lecture for chapter 18 on the stars."

The audio begins with a male speaker expressing gratitude and inviting continued participation in his lectures. Following this is a male speaker promoting an episode of "10 Minute Astronomy" and encouraging viewers to explore the playlist and other videos on his channel, ending with a request to subscribe.
